metadata.title: Reducing Frictional Power Losses and Improving the Scuffing Resistance in Automotive Engines Using Hybrid Nanomaterials as Nano-Lubricant Additives

sections.text:
The purpose of this work was to investigate a new nano-additive for improved internal combustion engine oils designed for increased fuel economy and a cleaner environment. The friction and wear characteristics of nano-lubricants containing hybrid nano-materials of Al2O3 and TiO2 were been evaluated under reciprocating test conditions to simulate a piston ring/cylinder liner contact. Al2O3/TiO2 nanoparticles were suspended in a commercially available lubricant in various concentrations. The Al2O3 and TiO2 nanoparticles had sizes of 8-12 nm and 10 nm, respectively. The morphology and microstructure of the tribofilms produced during frictional contact were investigated via FE-SEM, EDS and a 3-D surface profiler. In the best case, there was a reduction of frictional power losses for the simulated piston ring assembly by 40-51% compared to a commercially available lubricant. The nano-additive composition in that case was 0.05 wt.% Al2O3+0.05 wt.% TiO2. Moreover, the wear rate of piston ring decreased by 17% after a sliding of 50 km due to the delamination of Al2O3 and TiO2 nanoparticles on worn surfaces. In that case, they acted as a solid lubricant to reduce both wear and scuffing. These results present a
promising and straightforward approach to automotive fuel economy and an increased life span for engine parts. Keywords: Hybrid nano-lubricants, frictional power losses, anti-scuffing, anti-wear, piston ring assembly.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
The key challenge for improving the performance and fuel economy of internal combustion engines is the reduction of frictional power losses. Total power generated by an engine is decreased approximately between 17% and 19% because of frictional losses between engine parts [1]. To reduce the total frictional losses in automotive engines, it is imperative to improve the tribological characteristics of the piston ring assembly because it makes a contribution of about 40% to 50% to the total frictional losses [2, 3]. In the recent years, nanomaterials have attracted increasing interest and have been used in a lot of energy related fields because of their unusual mechanical, electrical, and piezoelectric properties [4]. In nano-lubricants, some nanomaterials are added to lubricating engine oils to improve the tribological properties via the formation of a protective film on surfaces and create a rolling effect between sliding surfaces [5, 6].
Aluminum and titanium oxides (Al2O3 and TiO2) are characterized by excellent lubricating properties and are thus widely applied as nano-lubricant additives [7]. Solid lubricants are materials that can exhibit very low friction during sliding under extreme conditions of temperature and loads in the absence of external supply of lubricant [8]. Binu et al. presented tribological properties of TiO2/SiO2 nanocomposites with grease. The results revealed that the load-carrying capacity increased by 40% in comparison to the situation without the use of nanomaterials [9]. Nanoparticles make use of ball bearings that utilize a rolling mechanism to decrease friction between the worn surfaces [10]. Wear rate was decreased by incorporating TiO2 nanoparticles into epoxy composites under high pressure and high speed [11]. TiO2 is known to
display high resistance to water corrosion [12]. All of these studies show that improvements in friction and anti-wear properties of the nanocomposite. Solid lubricants have also been contended to arise from deposition nanoparticles on the worn surfaces [13]. Kim et al. [14] proved that adding SiO2 nanoparticles in polyalphaolefin (PAO) is an effective means for reducing the friction, anti-wear and enhance mechanical characteristics of surfaces. The formation and removal of tribo-boundary films are dynamic processes under the control of the interaction between the surface of nanoparticles and the lubricated friction surfaces [15].
Nanomaterials with sizes significantly smaller than 100 nm have thermal conductivities higher than those of the fluids [16]. The experimental tests on engine showed that the surface texture of piston rings can reduce the engine fuel consumption up to 4% [17]. Reduction in the viscosity helps to minimize the frictional power losses from viscous work and achieve a lowering of fuel consumption by 0.2-2.5% [18]. Piston ring assembly is an essential part in an automotive engine for converting the heat energy into mechanical power. The increase of the power losses due to friction increases fuel consumption [19]. More than 60% of the power supplied to an engine is consumed as heat exchanged through the worn surfaces and the gases exhaust with high temperature [20].
The lubrication regimes of internal combustion engines can be classified into three general categories: boundary, mixed, and hydrodynamic lubrication. The lubrication for the ring-liner contact is a boundary or mixed at the top and bottom dead center (TDC and BDC) positions, but at mid-stroke is hydrodynamic lubrication [21]. Boundary lubrication is expected to occur during starting, stopping, and periods of severe operation [2]. The addition of nanoparticles to lubricants can reduce friction, particularly under boundary and mixed lubrication conditions due to the formation of a tribo-boundary film on the worn surface [22]. It also improves anti-wear ability, extreme pressure and load bearing capacity [23]. Furthermore, nanomaterials were added to
engine oil as additives in order to improve the properties such as oil viscosity index and thermal conductivity [24].
Nanoparticles become polished and inlaid into the friction surfaces, forming a tribo-boundary film that prevented the worn surfaces from direct contact. Nonetheless, surface hardness increased because of the bearing effect of nanoparticles between the frictional surfaces [25]. Al2O3 nanomaterials are categorized as ceramic nanoparticles [26]. Although the thermal conductivity of Al2O3 nanoparticles is not high in comparison with CuO and ZnO, the heat transfer in fluids is higher [27]. There is usually a thermal conductivity improvement with an increase in nanomaterials concentration in lubricants [28]. Nano-lubricants consisting of zirconia (ZrO2) nanoparticles and reduced graphene oxide (GO) nanosheets showed reduction of the friction and wear [29]. Several mechanisms have been presented to describe the nano-lubricant properties, including the conversion of the pure sliding friction to the mixed sliding-rolling friction [30], the formation of a self-laminating protective film [31], mending effect [32] and polishing effect [33].
The hybrid nanoparticles exhibited properties that do not exist in the individual material as well as the synergistic effect of the nanoparticles [34]. Luo et al. [35] presented tribological properties of Al2O3/TiO2 nanocomposite blends with lubricating oil. The Al2O3/TiO2 nanoparticles used in the experiments had an average grain size of 75 nm. The Al2O3/TiO2 nanocomposites were suspended in lubricating oil in different concentrations (0.05, 0.5, 0.1, and 1 wt.%) for formulating the nano-lubricants. The results showed that modified Al2O3/TiO2 nanocomposites as additives can significantly reduce friction coefficients by 20.51% and improve anti-wear performances under an optimal concentration of 0.1 wt.%. Furthermore, Al2O3/TiO2 nanoparticles exhibit better anti-wear resistance than the pure Al2O3 or TiO2. Another study also demonstrated that using 80 nm of grain size of Al2O3/TiO2 hybrid nanoparticles at a 0.1 wt.%
concentration reduced the friction coefficient by 14.75% [36]. Wei et al. [37] investigated the influence of ZrO2/SiO2 composite nanoparticles on tribological properties. The results indicated that the average reduction of the friction coefficient by 16.24% using a grain size of 50-80 nm for a concentration of 0.1 wt.%. Murakami et al. [38] reported that hybrid additives used in lubricant can lead to an increase in pressure of the lubricant and a reduced friction coefficient.
For this reason, the current work presents a comprehensive study of the tribological properties of piston ring/cylinder liner interface in an engine using Al2O3/TiO2 hybrid nanoparticles as nanolubricant additives. In addition, Al2O3/TiO2 hybrid nano-lubricants were discussed to understand the mechanisms responsible for reducing the frictional power losses using field emission scanning electron microscopy (FE-SEM, ZEISS ULTRA PLUS), energy dispersive spectroscopy (EDS, Inca X-Act) and Nanovea ST400 3D Profilometer (non-contact profilometer) for analyzing the worn surfaces. The study provides insights into how Al2O3/TiO2 hybrid nano-lubricant additives could contribute towards energy saving and improved fuel economy in automotive engines.

sections.heading: 2.1 Characterization of Al2O3/TiO2 Hybrid Nano-lubricants
sections.text:
Al2O3 and TiO2 nanoparticles are the most appropriate for many tribological applications such as coating because of its excellent tribological behavior. It is well known that the Al2O3 is classified as hard phase. The base lubricant used in this study was commercially available synthetic oil (Castrol EDGE professional A5 5W-30). The Al2O3 and TiO2 powders were purchased from Nanjing XFNANO Materials Tech Co., Ltd. The average sizes of the Al2O3 and TiO2 nanoparticles were 8-12 nm and 10 nm, respectively. The Al2O3 and TiO2 nanomaterials were observed using FE-SEM. Figure 1 shows the FE-SEM image of the Al2O3 and TiO2 nanoparticles. The morphology of the Al2O3 and TiO2 nanoparticles was fairly spherical.
Fig. 1 FE-SEM micrographs for (a) Al2O3 nanoparticles and (b) TiO2 nanoparticles.
The compositions of nano-lubricant comprised Al2O3/TiO2 hybrid nanoparticles in concentration of 0.05, 0.1, 0.25, and 0.5 wt.% placed with oleic acid in concentration of 1.95, 1.9, 1.75 and 1.5 wt.%, respectively. The oleic acid was purchased from Tianjin Fuchen Chemical Reagent Factory of China. In present study, Al2O3/TiO2 hybrid nano-lubricants comprised 2 wt.% additive solution (Al2O3/TiO2+oleic acid) and 98 wt.% engine oil (5W-30) as shown in Table 1.
Table 1 The synthesis of Al2O3/TiO2 hybrid nano-lubricants Concentration (wt. %) Standard oil (5W-30) Additive solution
0.05 98% Oil 2% Al2O3/ TiO2 Solution (0.025 % Al2O3 + 0.025 % TiO2 + 1.95 % oleic acid) 0.1 98% Oil 2% Al2O3/ TiO2 Solution (0.05 % Al2O3 + 0.05 % TiO2 + 1.9 % oleic acid) 0.25 98% Oil 2% Al2O3/ TiO2 Solution (0.125 % Al2O3 + 0.125 % TiO2 + 1.75 % oleic acid)
0.5 98% Oil 2% Al2O3/ TiO2 Solution (0.25 % Al2O3 + 0.25 % TiO2 + 1.5 % oleic acid)
To study the crystal structures and phases of Al2O3 and TiO2 nanomaterials, all nanoparticles
were analyzed by XRD. A comparison of the XRD patterns of Al2O3 and TiO2 is illustrated as Fig. 2. It can be observed that the peak details are 2θ = 25.2°, 36.9°, 48°, 53°, 55° and 62° with
strong diffraction peaks at 25° and 48° confirms TiO2 in the anatase structure phase. However, Al2O3 nanoparticles also show the typical diffraction peaks (311), (400) and (441) at 2θ= 37°, 45° and 67°, respectively. From XRD patterns, an intensity of XRD peaks of the Al2O3 and TiO2 reflects that the nanoparticles are broad diffraction peaks (means poor crystallization), which indicates very small size crystallite [39]. The XRD data was analyzed with the assistance of MDI Jade 6 program.
Fig. 2 XRD patterns of Al2O3 and TiO2 nanoparticles.
One of the substantial nano-lubricant properties is the rate of dispersion and stability of
nanoparticles in the engine oil. When dispersion of Al2O3/TiO2 nanomaterials in the engine oil is not stable, it is possible that agglomeration and precipitation of nanoparticles would occur, which may cause damage to the sliding surfaces. To disperse nanomaterials inside the engine oil, oleic acid was used for preparing the nano-lubricant samples in different concentrations using magnetic stirrer for 4 hours in engine oil to get a homogeneous and stable suspension. Oleic acid plays the
important role of facilitating the mixing of nanoparticles to make them soluble in the engine oil. In the present study, in order to monitor the stability of nano-lubricants, the absorption spectra of nano-lubricants was measured using the UV−visible spectroscopy to detect aggregation of nanoparticles for different time intervals of 48, 168, 336 and 1000 hours as shown in Fig. 3. The stability of nano-lubricants about 336 hours, but the stability decreased clearly after 1000 hours.
Fig. 3 The optical absorbance spectrum for Al2O3/TiO2 hybrid nano-lubricants sample with different times.

sections.heading: 2.2 Tribotest Rig Description
sections.text:
The tribometer test bench was designed to mimic the sliding reciprocating motion of the piston ring/cylinder liner interface in an engine. Figure 4 illustrates the designed test rig of the piston ring assembly. This setup can be used to perform friction tests of the piston ring and the cylinder liner under lubricating conditions according to ASTM G181-11 [40]. The main structural features of the test rig are shown in Fig. 4. An AC motor with variable angular velocity drives the crank
mechanism facilitates a reciprocal motion of the cylinder liner segment along the two guides fixed on a common base isolated from the laboratory floor by special elastomer damping pads to reduce the effect of test rig vibration on the measured parameters. The stroke length was fixed at 65 mm. The piston ring sample was placed under the pivot arm above a reciprocating cylinder liner segment in a specially designed piston ring holder. The application of the normal load to the piston ring and cylinder was via the use of dead weights at the end of an arm.
A piezoelectric, two-axis force transducer and charge amplifier were used to measure the normal force and friction force generated on the piston ring during sliding. The natural frequency response of this sensor facilitated the behaviour analysis of the friction during the reciprocating motion. The signals generated were received and processed using the DEWESoft 6.6.7 program for data acquisition connected to a PC to record the frictional force in real time during the experiment. Piston ring and cylinder liner samples were used as the test specimens cut from actually fired engine components, ensuring that the materials tested are the same as in the vehicle engine by using the test rig. The hardness of the friction samples were according to the standards stipulated in ref. [41]. The average hardness of the piston ring surface was 320 VH (Vickers hardness), whilst the hardness for the cylinder liner was 413 VH.
Alignment and centering of the piston ring and cylinder liner in setup are a critical factor to realizing the conformal contact between the ring and the liner samples. In order to avoid the problems of alignment in matching curvatures of the ring and the liner, the piston ring samples were installed in a specially designed ring holder, which consists of a portion of the ring groove of the matching ring. The liner specimen was held in the reciprocating part and secured by screws allowing for axial and lateral alignment of the liner (Fig. 4b). Contact pressure measurements were inversely related to the contact area measurements. In this setup, the Fuji film Prescale
method [42] was used to check the conformability of the contact area between the piston ring and the cylinder liner.
Fig. 4. The designed bench tribometer of the piston ring/cylinder liner interface. (a) Photograph of the bench tribometer, (b) Schematic of the tribometer. The main components of the test rig: 1- Test rig base, 2- Electric motor, 3- Speed control, 4- Chain, 5- Bearings, 6- Crank mechanism, 7- Reciprocating block, 8,16- Guides, 9- Balls, 10- Cylinder liner sample, 11- Piston ring sample, 12- Piston ring holder, 13- 2-D force transducer, 14,15- Leverage system, 17- Bearing base, 18- Electric motor base.

sections.heading: 2.3 Tribological Tests Characterization
sections.text:
Tribological performance of Al2O3/TiO2 hybrid nano-lubricants was evaluated via measured and calculated the friction coefficient, power losses and the wear rate of the piston ring. The tribological experiments were conducted at an oil temperature of 100 o C to simulate top dead centre (TDC) position near the surface of the cylinder liner temperature. The applied normal force ranged from 40 to 230 N, which corresponds to pressures ranging from 0.86 to 5 MPa, respectively. This pressure represents the maximum nominal radial pressure applied after combustion under 50% of maximum engine load [43]. The contact loads were chosen to clarify the boundary, mixed and hydrodynamic lubrication. The average sliding speed was varied from 0.5 m s -1 to 1.45 m s -1
. An evaluation of the tribological behavior of Al2O3/TiO2 hybrid nano-
lubricants used the same amount (5 ml) of nano-lubricants to simulate starvation condition, which help in confirming the effect Al2O3/TiO2 hybrid nano-lubricants.
In order to evaluate the tribological behavior for nano-lubricant, the friction coefficient (µ) was
accessed as:

Where, is the frictional force (N) and is the normal load applied on ring (N).
The frictional power losses (P) can be calculated according the formula presented as follows:
P = = µ [R (sin + sin 2 )] (2)
Where, is the reciprocating sliding speed (m s -1 ), R is apparatus crank shaft radius (m), is angular velocity of the crank (rad s -1 ), L is apparatus connecting rod length (m) and is crank angle (degrees). The average reciprocating sliding velocity (Vavg.) can be calculated with the known angular velocity and crank shaft radius according the formula presented as follows:
Vavg. =

The wear rate of the piston ring was calculated using the following formula:
Specific wear rate =
(4)
Where, is worn volume (mm3), is the normal load applied on ring (N) and S is the sliding distance (m). The extent of wear for the ring was determined via the profiles of the worn scar cross-section measured using a surface profilometer. Before each test, the frictional specimens were cleaned by acetone using a magnetic stirrer for about 10 min and dried to remove any contamination on surfaces. Each friction test was carried for the duration of 20 min. The friction and wear tests were carried out at least three times under the same conditions in an attempt to replicate experimental results, after which the average results were taken to minimize measurement error.
3. Results and Discussions
3.1 Evaluation of the Tribological Behavior for Al2O3/TiO2 Nano-lubricants The average friction coefficient of the piston ring assembly with different concentrations of Al2O3/TiO2 hybrid nanoparticles in engine oil under 0.5 m s -1 average sliding speed and a contact pressure of 1.95 MPa are shown in Fig. 5. From the results, it can be observed that the friction coefficient decreased by 47.61% for the use of Al2O3/TiO2 hybrid nano-lubricants under 0.1 wt.% concentration, as compared to the engine oil without nanoparticles. Moreover, the use of oleic acid alone in the engine oil contributes to a reduction in the friction coefficient by 18% due to a chemical reaction on the worn surfaces as shown by the work done by another author [44]. Therefore, the optimum concentration (0.1 wt.%) of Al2O3/TiO2 hybrid nanoparticles, for the current study, was consistent with literature reports [35, 36]. For this reason, we focused on a concentration of 0.1 wt.% in the current study to show the enhancement in the tribological
behavior. It was observed that the reduction of the friction in our work was higher than previous studies [35, 36]. Furthermore, Al2O3/TiO2 hybrid nano-lubricants exhibited the greatest reduction in friction coefficient for all concentrations of the nanoparticles (Fig. 5) owing to the synergistic effect of the nanoparticles, as compared with the individual nanoparticles (Al2O3 or TiO2 nanolubricant).
points in the stroke depending on operating conditions (load, speed and temperature) as well as the contact geometry and the surface topography. These changes alter the lubrication regime, which determines the mechanisms of friction. The total friction consists of hydrodynamic friction due to shearing of lubricant and boundary friction at asperity contact locations. Boundary and mixed lubrication regimes occur near the ends of stroke (TDC and BDC), but hydrodynamic lubrication occur at mid-stroke.
An important observation from the friction results is that during the piston travel over the stroke, the maximum of friction coefficient value is reached at the top and bottom dead center (TDC and BDC) owing to the increase in the metal contact between worn surfaces (boundary lubrication). While, the maximum frictional power losses were observed at mid-stroke location, reaching zero at (TDC and BDC) positions as shown in Fig. 6b. This might be due to the low sliding speed. The sliding speed reached its maximum at mid-stroke causing an increase in the shear stress in the lubricant film, increasing the frictional power losses as a consequence. Generally, there was an increase in the frictional power losses with an increase in engine speed. Based on the obtained results, it was evident that Al2O3/TiO2 hybrid nano-lubricants can significantly reduce the friction coefficient and friction power losses by 40-51%. The main reasons for the decrease in friction coefficient for hybrid nano-lubricants is the ability of the nanoparticles to change pure sliding friction into rolling friction due to reduced interfacial interaction for frictional surfaces (vdW interactions and Coulomb) and deposition of tribo-film on worn surfaces.
Fig.6 Tribological behavior of piston ring assembly with and without Al2O3/TiO2 hybrid nano-
lubricants under 0.5 m s -1 average sliding speed and 2.6 MPa contact pressure.
The kinematic viscosity of the engine oil (5W-30) without and with Al2O3/TiO2 hybrid nanoparticles for the best sample of nano-lubricant (0.05 wt.% Al2O3+0.05 wt.% TiO2+1.9% oleic acid+98% base oil) at two temperatures 40 °C and 100 °C was measured. The kinematic viscosity and viscosity index of Al2O3/TiO2 hybrid nano-lubricants measured was based on the GB/T265-1988 and GB/T1995-1998 lubricant testing standards. Generally, the kinematic viscosity of engine oil decreased with increasing temperature. The kinematic viscosity of Al2O3/TiO2 hybrid nano-lubricants recorded at the temperatures of 40 °C and 100 °C slightly decreased. On the other hand, the viscosity of an engine oil containing oleic acid was decreased by only a small amount as shown in Fig. 7a. The spherical nature of the nanoparticles plays an important role in the rheological behavior [45]. Further investigation will be required to evaluate the main mechanism of the kinematic viscosity reduction via the use of the Al2O3/TiO2 hybrid nano-lubricant and interactions of the nanoparticles with the engine oil.
Fig. 7 Effect of Al2O3/TiO2 hybrid nano-lubricants on kinematic viscosity in (a) and viscosity index in (b).
Additionally, the results showed that the viscosity index of the nano-lubricants was increased by
1.87% as compared to the commercial lubricant (Fig. 7b). The increase of the viscosity index indicates a low viscosity change with temperature increase. Finally, Al2O3/TiO2 hybrid nano-
lubricants provide low viscosity and high viscosity index, which lead to reduced frictional losses through shear thinning of the oil film. This reduction of power losses further enhances the automotive engine efficiency.
The curves in Fig. 8 exhibits the wear rates of the piston ring with sliding distance for
commercial lubricant and nano-lubricants under 5 MPa contact pressure and 0.66 m s -1 average sliding speed. The wear rate of ring increasing with an increase in the sliding distance because of the worn surface is no longer able to support the oxide layer and wear changes from tribooxidation to adhesion. It is clearly seen that Al2O3/TiO2 hybrid nano-lubricants can significantly reduce the wear rate of the ring by 17% after a sliding distance of 50 km, in comparison with commercial lubricant due to formation of a tribo-boundary film on worn surfaces.
regimes. Using different of loads to simulate lubrication regimes of the piston ring assembly. The Stribeck parameter [46, 47] according the formula presented as follows:
Stribeck parameter =
(5)
Where, is average sliding speed (m s -1 ) and is load unit (N m -1 ).
In these tests, the average reciprocating sliding speed was constant and the viscosity influences were neglected, so the Stribeck curve presented here only involved the effect of the load. This approach allows the determination of a particular lubrication mode as well as the range of friction coefficients. In order to maintain the boundary lubrication regime, the load kept high. The value of the friction coefficient was noticed to be high, ranging from 0.02 to 0.14 in boundary and mixed lubrication regimes. The experimental data is presented in the Stribeck curve format to illustrate the effect of load establishing lubrication regimes of the piston ring assembly as shown in Fig. 9.
Fig. 9 Average friction coefficient versus the modified Stribeck parameter via Al2O3/TiO2 hybrid nano-lubricants.
The results showed that the use of hybrid nano-lubricants reduced the friction coefficient by 47, 33 and 9 % under boundary, mixed and hydrodynamic lubrication, respectively. The friction coefficient was reduced because of the mechanism of Al2O3/TiO2 hybrid nanoparticles and formation tribo-film on surfaces. As a result of that, the transition for point (A) for mixed lubrication means that there is a shift of friction coefficient from mixed to approximately hydrodynamic (Fig. 9) owing to polishing effect via the presence nanoparticles as evident in the Fig. 11c, d. The positive effect of the transition point (A) is desirable in the scuffing resistance during sliding friction process.
Fig. 10 Mean friction coefficient during the stroke under different sliding speeds and 3 MPa contact pressure.
To illustrate the effect of the sliding speed on friction coefficient for both Al2O3/TiO2 hybrid lubricants and without nanoparticles (Fig. 10). The high sliding velocities lead to surface frictional heating and thus formation of a thin molten layer at the asperity contacts causing a reduced of the shear stress between friction surfaces. This could be attributed the mechanism for
hybrid nano-lubricants, which leads to the formation of a stable tribo-film, reducing the shear strength at the contact resulting in very low friction coefficient.

sections.heading: 3.2 Composition and Morphology of the Tribo-chemistry Films on the Worn Surfaces
sections.text:
The scuffing happens when the rate of thermal softening because of frictional heating generated exceeds the rate of heat dissipation for frictional surfaces at contact interface [48]. The scuffing is affected by material, surface finish, contact pressure, temperature, sliding velocity and lubricant properties. After a 15 km sliding distance under 4 MPa contact pressure and 0.6 m s -1 average sliding speed. The worn surface of the piston ring using commercial lubricant showed severe plastic deformation and exfoliation as shown in Fig. 11a, b. Figure 11b reveals clearly the scuffing marks on piston ring surface. The worn surfaces appear as if they had been welded together at discrete points causing adhesive removal of the ring surface material (scuffing). Scuffing wear is completely different from other types of wear. The reason for this is that, it occurs when there is a breakdown of lubricant film thickness due to starvation of lubrication between the ring and liner. During high speed and high load between frictional surfaces, it leads to a cold welding process owing to high flash temperature at asperity contact. The continuation of this situation for a short duration results in scuffing wear. During scuffing there is a transfer of the particles from surface of low hardness to surface of greater hardness (from ring to liner). Scuffing wear is purely based on the adhesive tendencies. Due to severe scuffing damage, the friction coefficient, frictional power losses and wear rate of the piston ring at use of commercial lubricant (5W-30) was very high, as shown in Fig. 6 and Fig. 8, respectively.
The addition of Al2O3/TiO2 hybrid nanoparticles in engine using 0.1 concentration can fill scars and grooves, as well as cover wide scratches in the worn region as shown in Fig. 11c, d. Nonetheless, hybrid nano-lubricants chemically react with surfaces to form a tribo-boundary film that deposits above the frictional surfaces and so reduce the friction coefficient and power losses
as shown in Fig. 6. Hence, the wear rate of the piston ring is also reduced as compared to the commercial lubricant as revealed in Fig. 8. It has been increased of the scuffing resistance owing to self-laminating protective films, which formed on worn surfaces as a solid lubricant.
Fig. 11 Improving the scuffing resistance of piston ring under 4 MPa contact pressure and 0.6 m s -1 average sliding speed, (a, b) in commercial lubricant and (c, d) Al2O3/TiO2 hybrid nanolubricants using 0.05 wt.% Al2O3 and 0.05 wt.% TiO2.
The EDS patterns with elemental content of tested piston ring and cylinder liner presenting nanoparticles deposition are shown in Fig. 12. Figure 12b, d confirms that Al2O3 and TiO2 nanoparticles were deposited on the ring and liner surface, thus explaining the lower friction coefficient and frictional power losses owing to tribo-boundary film prevents direct contact between the asperities observed in Fig. 6. The worn surface of the ring and liner when commercial lubricant without nanoparticles was used showed mix of abrasive and adhesive wear.
The results are showed that a high value of surface roughness for ring and liner (1.53 μm and 0.55 μm) at using commercial lubricant as shown in Fig. 13a, c. Moreover, the exfoliation for the surfaces leads to increased surface roughness and increase asperity contact area (Fig. 11a). In hybrid nano-lubricants, the surface roughness of the piston ring and liner decreased by 64.7 % and 40 %, respectively, compared to commercial lubricant without nanoparticles as shown in Fig. 13b, d. Al2O3/TiO2 Hybrid nano-lubricants can be deposited on the worn surfaces to form a physical tribo-film owing to the small average diameter of nanoparticles being smaller than the surface roughness, which could fill scars and grooves of the surfaces causing a decline in surface roughness (mending and polishing effects). Nonetheless, the reduction in surface roughness for ring and liner can increase the scuffing resistance and allow the surface to bear higher load and temperature.
The EDS element mapping in Fig. 14 displays the nanostructure and chemical composition of the tribo-boundary film and plastic deformation zone of the piston ring surface when lubricated by Al2O3/TiO2 hybrid nano-lubricants under 4 MPa contact and 0.6 m s -1 average sliding speed after a sliding distance of 15 km. It is clear that the Al2O3 and TiO2 are present in the tribo-boundary film formed on ring surface. The tribo-boundary film is rich in Al2O3 and TiO2. This indicates a contribution of Al2O3 and TiO2 in protective film formation, which to be responsible about the minimization of frictional power losses, anti-wear and anti-scuffing provided by Al2O3/TiO2 hybrid nano-lubricants.
A tribo-boundary film can be formed on the frictional surfaces through chemical reaction and physical mechanism. In chemical reactions, nano-lubricants that contain active elements such as Phosphorus (P), Sulfur (S), Chlorine (Cl) as shown in Fig. 15. These lubricant additives react with surfactant and substrate surface of friction pairs causing the formation of a tribochemical film and deposited in the frictional surfaces of ring and liner. Furthermore, the nanoparticles play a dominant role at high temperatures and pressure. The tribochemical reaction occurs during a sliding friction between the ring and the liner due to the local high contact pressure and flash temperature caused by the rupture and collision of the asperities of frictional surfaces. It is possible that there is thermal activation leading to the lubricity of Al2O3/TiO2 hybrid nanoparticles, which is most likely related to the chemical interaction with the worn surfaces and formation of a tribochemical film as a solid lubricant. The deposition of tribochemical film on the worn surfaces is a possible explanation to improving of the tribological behavior due to decreases of shearing stress. However at the same time, a physical film is formed by the mending effect of metal oxide nanoparticles. These Al2O3/TiO2 hybrid nanoparticles in engine oil can fill scars and grooves of the rubbing surfaces to help the separation parts and reduce asperity contact. Finally, the physical mechanism is associated with tribochemical reactions.
For achieving effective and successful lubrication mechanism of piston ring assembly in automotive engines, the film formation rate has to be equal to or greater than the film removal rate and strong adhesion and cohesion with substrate surfaces. For this reason, the tribochemical nanoparticles interaction mechanism is crucial for achieving successful lubrication. Based on the experimental evidence for nano-lubricants was detected the presence active elements such as P (active element of ZDDP). This suggests involvement of both Al2O3/TiO2 hybrid nanoparticles, oil additive package, specifically zinc dialkyldithio-phosphate (ZDDP) in base engine oil (5W30) with substrate surface to formation tribo-boundary film. This confirms the synergistic effects between Al2O3/TiO2 hybrid nanoparticles and ZDDP, which contributes to the reduction in the friction and frictional power losses leading to improved tribological behavior in automotive engines.
Fig. 15 EDS spectrum at cross-section of piston ring surface lubricated by Al2O3/TiO2 hybrid nano-lubricants (spectrum 16) in Fig. 14.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusions
sections.text:
The findings of this study lead to the conclusion that Al2O3/TiO2 hybrid nano-lubricants can contribute to an improvement in the efficiency of engines and fuel economy in automotive engines via the reduction of frictional power losses. The following conclusions can be drawn: 1- The morphology of the worn surfaces of the ring and liner indicates that a protective film
formation on the worn surfaces takes the form of a solid lubricant or an ultra-thin lubricating coating, which is responsible for the minimization of frictional power losses, as well as the anti-wear and anti-scuffing ability provided by Al2O3/TiO2 hybrid nanoparticles and the oil additive package (Phosphorus active element of ZDDP) in the fully formulated base engine oil (5W-30). 2- The frictional power losses for the piston ring assembly were reduced by 40-51% for the
Al2O3/TiO2 hybrid nano-lubricants, as compared with the commercial lubricant (5W-30). This could lead to an improved performance and fuel economy of an automotive engine. 3- The friction coefficient decreased by 47.61% under the boundary lubrication regime for the
use of the Al2O3/TiO2 hybrid nano-lubricants as compared with the engine oil without nanoparticles. Moreover, the use of oleic acid alone in engine oil contributes to a friction coefficient reduction by 18% due to chemical reaction on worn surfaces. 4- The surface roughness of the piston ring and liner while using 0.1 wt.% optimum
concentrations for Al2O3/TiO2 hybrid nano-lubricants decreased by 64.7% and 40%, respectively, compared with the commercial lubricant. 5- The wear rate of the piston ring decreased by 17% due to the delamination mechanism by the
Al2O3/TiO2 hybrid nanoparticles for worn surfaces leading to a reduced metal contact between worn surfaces.
Notes The authors declare no competing financial interest.

sections.heading: ACKNOWLEDGMENTS
sections.text: The authors would like to express their deep appreciation to the Hubei Key Laboratory of Advanced Technology for Automotive Components and State Key Laboratory of Advanced Technology for Materials Synthesis and Processing (Wuhan University of Technology) for continuous support. M.K.A. Ali and R.F. Turkson acknowledge the Chinese Scholarship Council (CSC) for financial support for their PhD studies in the form of CSC grant Numbers 2014GF032 and 2013GXZ993 respectively. M.K.A. Ali also appreciates the financial support from the Egyptian Government. We also wish to thank the various anonymous reviewers for their helpful and valuable comments.

metadata.abstractText: The purpose of this work was to investigate a new nano-additive for improved internal combustion engine oils designed for increased fuel economy and a cleaner environment. The friction and wear characteristics of nano-lubricants containing hybrid nano-materials of Al2O3 and TiO2 were been evaluated under reciprocating test conditions to simulate a piston ring/cylinder liner contact. Al2O3/TiO2 nanoparticles were suspended in a commercially available lubricant in various concentrations. The Al2O3 and TiO2 nanoparticles had sizes of 8-12 nm and 10 nm, respectively. The morphology and microstructure of the tribofilms produced during frictional contact were investigated via FE-SEM, EDS and a 3-D surface profiler. In the best case, there was a reduction of frictional power losses for the simulated piston ring assembly by 40-51% compared to a commercially available lubricant. The nano-additive composition in that case was 0.05 wt.% Al2O3+0.05 wt.% TiO2. Moreover, the wear rate of piston ring decreased by 17% after a sliding of 50 km due to the delamination of Al2O3 and TiO2 nanoparticles on worn surfaces. In that case, they acted as a solid lubricant to reduce both wear and scuffing. These results present a 2 promising and straightforward approach to automotive fuel economy and an increased life span for engine parts.
metadata.creator: Elsevier
